When we were finally seated at a nice corner circular booth, we did have a good waitress who was very cool.  I ordered Bob's Bad Breath Burger, which was pretty tasty, though while it said 'grass-fed,' it did seem like the patty was the pre-made frozen kind.  I wasn't overly blown away.  My friend's ordered the Carne Asada that looked ok, if you like a few cut pieces of steak over a bed of tortilla chips with some pico de gallo.  Again, didn't really blow my socks off.    As others have mentioned, it's LOUD.  They certainly pack a lot of tables into the two sides of the restaurant and waiters and waitresses are always squeezing behind you at the bar and between the close tables.  The old-school decor, however, is dark, warm and inviting, which I thought was a plus.  Make no mistake:  Weary Traveler is a place to be seen.  The locale on the Willy St. corner is great and there is a reason it is so busy.  The prices seemed reasonable, though I don't think I'll be itching to go back anytime soon.

Descriptive phrase: unpretentious hipster pub.  Normally when you hear you're going to a hip pub on Willy Street, you reach for your flannel and thick-rimmed glasses. Not that those would be out-of-place at Weary Traveler, but it's too generic and stereotypical. WT is more than just another place to comb crumbs out of your ironic mustache; it's legitamitely good and unique food and fun.  Come early because there's gonna be a wait. It's tight inside, but doesn't feel cramped. The dark and heavy wood and soft lighting make you feel like your in a friend's cabin. Four of us sat down to play some cards, drink some beers, and grab some grub.  They have a number of old-school games lying around to play while you wait. Their tap beer list is respectable, with pitchers running $12-$14. We split a Wisconsin Meat and Cheese Platter (Medium - $13.50 was enough for four) which featured turkey, ham, and sausage with a few different cheeses and crostinis. The crostinis were a bit stale, but the local meats were delicious. The (duck?) liver pate was a bit much for me.  My main course was the West of the Andes Sandwich ($8.75). Jeebus, that was good. Avocado, pico de gallo, and chipotle mayo atop perfectly grilled beef tenderloin. More than enough food for the price, and the quality was outstanding. Greasy enough to need napkins, but not so much to overpower the other tastes. Arguably one of the best sammiches in Madison. I subbed a special side of rice that night, but the usual mixed greens looked like a sad little addition.  Overall I had a wonderful experience at Weary Traveler. If you're in the area, definitely give it a try. There's few better places to spend some time with friends in the area.

That's it, I have eaten at the Weary Traveler at least one time too many, and I am never coming (or getting dragged) back.  I really, truly, do not understand what is supposed to be so great about this place.  It is crowded, loud, dark, dusty, and in my opinion, the last place I'd want to go with anyone, if only because I can't see or hear them.  The menu is pretty limited, and I think I always end up with the carne asada just because nothing else sounds remotely appealing.  The last time I had that dish, it was shockingly spicy -- others at the table had ordered it as well, and claimed that theirs was not, so I'm not sure if something got spilled on my plate or what, but it was pretty rough going to actually eat any of it.  In fact, my vague recollections of other meals here include everything being way over-spiced...  I picked at the small amount of meat, ignored the giant pile of tortilla chips, and wondered how it was, with all the restaurants in Madison, that I'd ended up there.  Despite my full-ish plate when she cleared, the server didn't inquire if I needed a box or if anything was wrong.  The last straw for me was some, uh, digestive difficulties we'll call it, post-meal and the following day.  I can't say for sure it was the carne asada, but I don't know what else it might have been.  So I don't care how "cool" people think this place is -- I'd give it pass.

A friend of mine told me I had to eat here when I was in Madison because the food was "really amazing". Turns out the food was terrible. No flavor. Bad service. Horrible decor. I mean there's a metal rod with a speaker on top right in the center of the dining room. It was the worst food related experience I've had in a long time. Maybe it was a bad night or the normal chef was sick or something. No idea. This place sucks though. I was really surprised at how many people were there eating. Blah blah blah..

Ended up here after we tried three other places with crazy long waits, despite it being after 8 pm. It ended up being a fortuitous bit of luck.   It's so cozy. Yes, you're sitting a bit close to fellow diners, but the lighting is warm, the vibe is "friends kitchen" and the food is really good.   I had the burger and even though I'm not much of a burger person, I was impressed and would go back for more. There's a slab of cream cheese on it and it was a bit too much for me, but when I took some of it off and spread it around, it was much better.   We were so happy to have stumbled upon this place and we'll definitely be back. A great way to end a day in Madison.
Bad Breath Burger Carne Asada  Could not stop saying "mmmmmmmmm" the entire meal.  Good atmosphere, good service.  What more can you ask for?

My most recent brunch experiences here at the Weary have made me up my star rating. Why is that?  Reason #1: Le Toast. OMG. This is what all French toast should be like. Thick (like over an inch) slices of homemade whole grain bread in this perfect cinnamon-y, almond-y, sweet-but-not-too-sweet batter...and with real maple syrup on the side. YUM. **Tip: Get a half order with a side of...  Reason #2: The bacon. The slices of bacon are also huge("double-thick cut" is no joke), and have been nice and crispy when I've gotten them.   Reason #3: The service. I gave the Weary 3 stars in the past for slow service, and I think if you hit it at a super-busy time, this can still be the case. However, the last couple of times I've gone the servers have been ultra friendly and attentive.

Had this Bob's bad breath burger that everyone is raving about and it is a MUST order!!! It was the best burger I've ever had and the potatoes that come on the side.....,dang they're doing something right! All if the food comes from local sources and they are every proud of it. It had a cool atmosphere. Without a doubt will be back here again!

I went here for brunch with a couple girlfriends. It is a cute little place on Willy Street and I was excited to give it a try.  The interior is very homey and features a lot of weird pictures and eclectic decorations. They have a bunch of board games and giant chess pieces up on a shelf. It is a fun place!  On the downside - it was freezing in there! They were very clearly making an effort to minimize this by having the main entrance be the back entrance so people coming in to the restaurant don't open the door and let the air in, but it was still pretty chilly.   The food was alright, and the service was a little slow, but no real complaints. I had a good time meeting up with my friends. :)

Best grilled cheese in Madison! Get it loaded with avacado and onion!! Love this place. Stopped here for the late risers brunch. The boyfriend got eggs and potatoes. He said the flavor was good but they were a little more oily than normal...still a favorite! Restaurant is a gem!!

We trekked out early for a Friday to make sure we didn't have to wait for a table. 6:15pm arrival - snagged the last table in the place. After that, there was a steady crowd hovering around the door, waiting for tables to turn over.    I really liked the energy of the place, bustling and warm with wood floors and tin ceilings.  We ordered a pitcher of Hopalicious ($14) which seemed to be less quantity-wise than four pints (about $4/ea), so you'd probably break about even to simply order the beer you want by the glass vs get a pitcher, just sayin'. The dinner menu was reasonably priced with many items in the $9-10 range and several veg options.  I opted for the stuffed butternut squash and the Mister got the dinner steak special.    45 minutes later... dinner came (wowzers, good thing I wasn't too hungry)!  Indeed, tables seated after us were somehow served dinner before us, but regardless, we were excited when our food finally arrived. The butternut squash was presented nicely, with a side salad and  topped with sliced avocado.  However, it was a bit dry and lacked much flavor besides regular ol' squashiness.  The steak  was undersized and over-cooked... yikes, a double whammy!  Even the veg at the table knew that sucker was nowhere close to being medium rare.  Fortunately our waitress was accommodating about sending it back and replacing it.     All in all, ambiance was great, prices were good, service was fine, food was underwhelming.  I'd be willing to give it another shot, but there are probably a number of other spots I'd plan on hitting up first...

Cute little place. Went on a Tuesday evening with 2 others and sat right away. We were a little bit confused as we walked in if we were supposed to seat ourselves or if there was a host somewhere. We ended up having to walk up to the bar and ask.. so I'm not sure what the protocol is. Anyway onto the food:  Bob's bad breath burger is so good! I would say the meat was a little bit too much for me (half-pounder) but I guess others would be happy. There is cream-cheese on it, which others may feel weird about, but I loved it! Side salad was perfect and  side potatoes were AMAZING. My friends asked me why I'm eating all of my sides first, which I dont usually do. Cup of chili that my friend got looked good. Big chunks of tomato and beef.   It's really dark inside so it's hard to see the details of some foods like chili.. but it didn't bother me with my burger. I would def come back for some dinner, beer, or weekend brunch. They also have board games, which I didn't play but would def come back for! It's pretty small, so I wouldn't be surprised if there was a wait to sit.

Ok four friends are looking at the area for lunch and throwing out suggestions, pizza pies, Mexican, grills and my one buddy ended you saying that this place has good burgers so away we went because I have only had drinks here and the food looked good.  Ok the brunch menu was in service and two of us are scratching our heads looking for good burgers on the menu, there is only one period which is the Bobs bad breath burger which neither of us wanted, we were looking for a list of burger options to choose from. My buddy is feverishly trying to talk us in to just getting it anyway which turns into cranky/spirited lecture of how I should have it how the chef makes it, FU#k no that's not what and I'm not getting it. I ask the server if I could get a bacon cheeseburger with lettuce, tomato and raw onion rare which she says is ok so that's what I got. My buddy try's to embarrass me by telling our server that I'm being difficult and the whole kitchen should spit in my burger, nice guy.  The burger came in a reasonable amount of time for how busy the place was and did it spectacular on the plate. It came with a side of greens and basically house made thick chips. During the lecture he says how he also hates how people salt their food before tasting it so I made it a point to pull the top bun off and salt the burger in front of him, former restaurant owners can be bitchy when dining with them.  The burger was so Fu#%ing good with the rare 1/2 patty having garlic in it and a nice grill flavor that just complemented the fresh lettuce, thick sliced tomatoes, raw red onion, crispy bacon and meaty cheese on a very fresh light bun. The garlic and grill flavor of the meat combined really set this burger apart from other burgers. The greens were good with a surprising heat finish that has a delay when eating them. I don't care at all for chips with any sandwich from a restaurant no matter how good they are, please give us frys because chips always appears as cheaping out on the plate.  This place is definitely worth stopping over for a burger even if it means a special request because of allergies or what ever and it's a cool place also.

First time visitor to the Weary Traveler. It's in a more hippie-ish liberal part of town (wait, what part of Madison is NOT liberal...nevermind). We were seated at a table too tightly positioned between two other tables, and the table wasn't level, so it rocked when you leaned on it. *pet peeve*.  The menu is not super extensive, but features a variety of food. You're likely to find something to try, but you may go more outside your comfort zone to get there if you are looking for standard bland American fare. I ordered the walleye sandwich. The sliced/fried red potatoes on the side were delicious. The walleye portion of the sandwich was great, but the bread/bun really overwhelmed the sandwich.  Service was adequate, but I felt as if they were rushing to get us to pay our bill and get out. I'm not sure I need to visit this restaurant again, but it was not horrible either. Parking in the area is pretty limited, though it has a very tiny lot behind the building.

okay. i know i "should" love this place and think i am in the minority here but - c'mon. every time i am at this place i feel like they (the staff) think they are doing  me a favor by letting me in.   had dinner w/ 3 others in late january and knew we were in for trouble from the start. first the "wrong server" came to our table, took our drinks order and disappeared. then the "right server" came to our table and said that the other person was mistaken. still no drinks. then the "wrong server" came back and apologized for the confusion. still no drinks. sooner or later, our drinks arrived and then we placed our dinner order. at the suggestion of the "right server" i got the pork chop special. a reasonable amount of time later, my table-mates dinners are served and i am informed it will be "just a few more minutes" for mine. my polite table-mates cannot be persuaded to start eating. . . 5, 10, 15, 20 minutes pass... at nearly the 25 minute mark, my food shows up, without apology, explanation, or accommodation.   c'mon.   i agree the food can be good, the atmosphere is fun, and the location is great but the service swings between disinterested and pretentious.   same goes for  nat spill (owned by the same person/family, if i'm not mistaken). i've got better ways and places to spend my money.

Tonight is cheap food review night.  This is the best bang for buck in town. you gotta come down to Willy street if you haven't tried!!!  This is a gastropub, more casual, more hipster than Graze, Forequarter or Merchant, BUT cheaper, and just as good!!!  And, its the one of the few late night places on Willy street!  What's good? Bob's bad breath is the best!!! I also love the chicken dijonnaise, its so tender and juicy... Don't forget to get EXTRA garlic potatoes! Tom Ka tofu; Not so vegan chilli and hungarian goulash are also really good for the winter weather!  I'm alright with cocktails there.  You can also play their board games!!! so awesome for a board games geek like me!  Lastly, they are crowded, weekdays or weekends; just come prepared. If you get a seat, food comes relatively quicklY!
Ok food, super busy, no place to wait.   Service was good....everything else was mediocre

Whenever I am back in town this place is a must! Everything on the menu is fantastic and the ambiance is cozy and terrific. Mom always gets the Catfish, a tasty nonalcoholic drink and faves about it. The burger is amazing, this is always what I recommend to carnivores, and I love the West Andes Snack plate. It is deliciously spicy!!! Thank goodness this place opened up in Madison, it gives me one more reason to visit.

If it is possible, and you desire,  to become hip and artistic by being near those who are then you should head over to the Weary Traveler. The food is great and the beer selection good. Really this place is the whole package.

The weary traveler can be loud when it's really crowded, but the food is so good.  My favorite is the bad breath burger.  The burger by itself is good, but then it's full of garlic and onions too.  I love this place.

The Weary Traveler is a great neighborhood spot and the perfect place to bring anyone new to Madison. The food is unique and tasty, the ambiance is relaxed and comfortable, and the game wall is a nice touch. Friday and Saturday evenings are always busy, so aim for a week night or a late night dinner. Service is always friendly, but sometimes slow.

The Weary Traveler Freehouse has really good food and drink.    I was in Madison over the weekend and stopped in this place for a burger and a beer.  I had the Bob's Bad Breath Burger and it was really really good.  The beer was super cold and the staff was more then friendly.    There was a ton of old hippies in this place, but the more I time in Madison, the more I came to realize, that number of old hippies had nothing to do with The Weary Traveler.  They old hippies may have bad taste in music, razors, soap, clothes, and footwear, but apparently they have great taste in food and spirits.   Check out the Weary Traveler.
Two words: Tuna Steak.  I'll drive across town for that.  Energetic atmosphere, usually busy and loud, but a nice crowd and good food.

The hippiest, hippest, & hipsterish locale bound to bring about not just weary travelers, but travellers from near, far, & beyond.  Ah... Near, Far, & Beyond brings back memories of a great friend, Paul, who was a vast landowner in one of the states in our great country. I'd often hear him joke about a store called Bed, Bath & Beyond, & make them about Bed & Breakfast type accommodation. He'd smirk, & I could perfectly recall his face, despite interacting with him on the phone, as he'd say, "that place that's called," Bed & Breakfast & Beyond". You get the general idea ;)  Similarly, The Weary Traveler Freehouse embodies a personal style all of its own influenced by Madison as one of the most free, hippest, & hippiest cities anywhere. A close competitor is Portfuckingland, Oregon, & Williamsburg, & Greenpoint in Brookfuckinglyn. That's in NYC for all of you outside the Milky Way, & the Andromeda galaxy. Atleast, that's where anyone from NYC thinks they're from when you meet New Yorkers internationally.   Non-New Yorker/non-American: "Where are you from?"   New Yorker: "Brooklyn"   (oh yes, Brooklyn is indeed the center of the Universe for hipsters, unless you're hailing from Portland, Oregon or Madison, Wisconsin).  Let's take a look at why The Weary Traveler Freehouse is a good example of all that is free, hippie, hip, & hipster:  You can only walk in from the side door (brings you to the establishment, & the restrooms galore). With philosophical, spiritual, footloose & fancy free posters, writing, travel photography, & eclectic messages all over from ceiling to floor. Yes, this is all inside on the walls within the restrooms. Walking towards another swinging door, & all in archaic print is further philosophical, religious, spiritual writing. I can't attest what it is, because I've never, infact, gotten a chance to read that vast writing. Usually as we set forth to the commencent of our evening here at Weary Traveler Freehouse, I am usually off to being present with company giving me little to no time to peruse the wall.   As you enter into another door within the Freehouse, you are bewitched by more antique posters, vintage decorations, photographs from the world, & plants.   This is just all the viewing, & wall "eye candy". I've yet to tell you anything about the restaurant or the service or the food.   FOOD Everything I've ever eaten has been nothing short of delicious. Everything on the menu is usually organic, local, & sustainably produced whether local or from sustainable parts of the USA. It's all rather simply cooked, baked, laden, & put on plates set forth. From your classic baked chicken to your Korean cold noodles to ice-cream pints from Calliope ice-cream. Some of the creamiest ice-cream in our country, but it's only available here as far as I know, & by contacting them.   That fantastically, & correctly baked chicken is good enough to make the chicken grease dripping down your chin a pure simple chicken luxury. From their grilled cheese loaded with avocado & onion to their West of the Andes Sandwich, it'll turn you into the best Mariachis singing aguacateeeee!!   Plus, you can add their wild Alaskan salmon for just a few extras to all their salads. The prices are for the kind of weary traveler who once traveled from Helsinki to Beijing by train via the Trans-Siberian, & Trans-Mongolian Railroads...Seeing majestic palaces, & museums of St. Petersburg, & Moscow, gazing into the endless expanse of Siberian grasslands, & forests, riding Bactrian camels up stunning Gobi sand dunes for a taste of the nomadic lifestyle, & strolling the ancient streets. I always feel at home back at the Weary Traveler even when I'm not traveling. After eating at the Weary Traveler, you too can be just like me, & take that trip. :)   Furthermore, they've got board games, & the beer is always tasty with an eclectic choice for all my late rising readers. Speaking of which, they've even got a brunch menu with a special list of choices called the Late Risers Brunch.   SERVICE  Very hippie meets hipster. Kind, relaxed, & maybe even border line sprezzatura. ;)   As fittingly as it's said for a place like The Weary Traveler, the message in small print on their website says: "BRIGHT PEOPLE ALWAYS READ THE FINE PRINT. CHOICE IS GOOD... AND YOU CHOSE AN INDEPENDENT RESTAURANT. - YOU ROCK."  9/2018

Weary Traveler is one of my local favorites,  a pretty distinctive expression of Madison's  Willie Street  sensibility that serves  interesting and distinctive dishes in a friendly and comfortable neighborhood atmosphere. Their interpretations of a reuben sandwich and burger (their justly celebrated "Bob's bad breath" burger) keep me coming back for lunch, and their carne asada makes a nice meal as well. I'm trying to make my way through some of their other dishes, each of which has its own creative elements. Much of what they do is locally sourced, with good veggie options. There are good non-alcoholic drink options, including their "catfish", a kind of fresh, tart lime-ade that i find especially refreshing, and a good iced tea and Sprecher root beers as well. I'm something of a regular, and I find service both competent and very friendly and welcoming. No waitrons here--the servers have real human personalities. Food can take a bit longer to come out than I would sometimes prefer, and their excellent potato side dish sometimes comes out lukewarm rather than hot. Their salad greens can be a bit bitter for my taste. But these are minor imperfections in a generally great place.

I love this place for the atmosphere and the delicious food.  I especially love The Weary Traveler for teaching me that vegetarian chili really can be as amazing as chili with meat.  If you're just in the mood for an intimate spot to get a drink with some friends, this is a central location  with good drinks and a great set up to get a group together.  The last time I went, they only took cash - - - just something to keep in mind!

It's very possible that if I were to move away from Madison (having lived here now for nearly 15 years) that upon a return visit, the Weary Traveler would be my first stop. This restaurant never disappoints. Their Old Fashioneds are some of the best in town.    Two of my favorite items on the menu include the Goulash and the West of the Andes Sandwich. Friends of mine swear by the Bad Breath Burger. The menu is on the smaller side but I've never gotten something I didn't like.   And save room for Key Lime Pie. One can almost guarantee when I go out for dinner I won't get dessert. The Weary Traveler is my exception to that rule.
Great atmosphere, usually busy, might have to wait for a table but good food and cozy environment.

The only thing to do in Madison is drink!  I loved this place as they had Hot Buttered Rum.  Always wanted to try that since reading Harry Potter.  I also had the Grog and let me tell you, the Grog is responsible for the third star.  My meal was good and tasty for bar food.  All bars are raising the bar on their food and this one is no different.  Really great and the service was amazing.  They do not separate bills which is so odd.  I will not go here again just for that reason.  It boggles the mind that a place with EPIC 10 mies away will not cater to groups.  NO wonder it is not crowded when we go.  This cannot be bourne for employees on work related trips.  We have to separate checks for our travel claims.  But all in all a great time.

I was so excited to finally make the trek to Willy to try the Weary Traveler. I've been itching to eat here for a while and Friday I was finally able to do so. We got there around 7 and the place was packed. We put our name in with the host (a little hard to find him by the way) and waited for about a half hour for our table. One complaint is that there isn't much room to wait. Yes, you can sit at the bar but otherwise you're stuck behind the curtain by the door that people are walking in and out of. I realize this is probably something that is unavoidable since the space isn't that big to begin with. It's just the one thing I didn't enjoy too much.  Once we were seated I decided to try the Wisconsin Cherry Seltzer. It was super refreshing and not too sweet. I really enjoyed it. One of my friends decided to order a cup of the Tom Ka Tofu soup which was AMAZING. I will return here just to order bowls and bowls of this soup! Not too sweet with just the right amount of heat. It was so yummy. For my meal I ordered the Med plate. I wasn't super hungry and hummus sounded good. It was plenty of food for me and came with a pretty large salad, some hummus and tabbouleh and homemade pita bread. The salad was yummy as was the hummus and tabbouleh. I wish they gave you more pita bread however - 5(ish) slices was just not enough to eat up all of the yummy things on that plate!   My friend and I decided to order a slice of the Tres Leches cake to finish off our meal. I am so glad we did, it was delicious. The cake was sweet and not soggy at all, and the whipped cream was very clearly homemade. It was a wonderful way to end the meal.   The price is right, the food is good, and the space is super cool. It took me too long to get here the first time and I can guarantee it won't take me as long to come back.

Bad. Breath. Burger.  Had to try the infamous Bob's Bad Breath Burger, and it lives up to it's name. Set in somewhat of a hole-in-the-wall place (somewhat easy to miss if you're not looking for it). I'd heard so much about this burger that I finally had to go. Talk about your garlic and onion overload. ALMOST too much garlic, especially on the chips (some felt soggy, as if they had been soaking in garlic.) Will definitely be back.
Nothing bad to say. Good wine, great food. I had the WILD caught salmon, always good, with wild rice , chard, zucchini and tomatoes...DELISH!

Having lived in Madison for over three years, I thought it was about time I checked out  the Weary Traveler. My husband and I live on the near west side and felt a little out of place on Willy St. but still find it a fun, eclectic place to be from time to time. When we walked in, the bartender immediately noticed that we may be looking for a table even though the place was pretty packed! He promised us a place to sit within ten minutes, then cheerfully served us up a beer while we waited. As we sipped our beers, we admired the fun decor and people-watched.   We were led to our cozy corner hi-top table within the promised time and our server was wonderful. He offered suggestions when asked, and seemed like he really enjoyed his job. I had it narrowed down to the reuben or the Bad Breath Burger, and ended up going with the burger. OMG. It was, hands down, the best burger I've ever had in my life!! My husband had the dijonaise chicken and he loved it too. He said "I wish I could have this sauce on everything!"  On top of the great food and service, the prices were extremely reasonable. We will be back!
Solid gastro pub with decent local and regional brews. Salad and bad breath burger stand out. Service was good as well.
Bob's badbreath buger with the garlic potatoes are out of this world!! Also check out their NessAlla Kombucha cocktails made in house... wow.

Bloody chicken! I am not talking about a minor little colorful juice or a bloody tinge or colored bone I mean a full on artery's worth of blood running out of my chicken. I tell the waitress and she gives me a crazy attitude and this BS about it being totally normal and that I am just doing it wrong. She said their chickens are all natural and that because they break it down themselves this happens. Well given the fact that the size of the thigh and leg were such that they obviously got a VERY young chicken it would obviously have more blood coming from the bone, but that is definitely not a sign of quality. Also breaking it down yourself or it being "all natural" doesn't mean anything. If anything extra blood is a sign you didn't defrost it fully before you cooked it. I had her throw it on the grill to cook it some more and when I got it it tasted fine despite her constant statements that it would be much too dry to enjoy. Sorry I don't need to be told what is quality or delicious don't tell me I am tasting it wrong or I don't know what I like. Do they honestly think I have never eaten a chicken from a farm, broken one down myself and baked it? I mean seriously it's chicken who hasn't eaten it?

I wandered into the Weary Traveler and saddled up to the bar both weary and hungry, having braved the frigid cold walk from my apartment.  The friendly wait staff served me up with a "West of the Andes" sandwich (w/ steak) and a tasty beer from one of their taps.  The sandwich was just the right size, scrumptious, and decently priced.  Service was quick around 5:30pm on a Saturday, but I have a feeling it gets quite busy later in the evening.  Looks to be a fun place to hang out with a group.

Visited for dinner on a Sunday. Originally we had planned to visit another restaurant in the area but they ended up being closed despite their hours saying otherwise. We were not disappointed with the change though!  We arrived on the early side of dinner and chose a table near the front. They had ample seating for larger groups, the table we chose could have seated six, so conversation was a bit tough for our group of four. No one to blame but ourselves for that though! Our server was very nice, but because it was early she was not super familiar with the specials yet. They had three specials and two of our group went with one of them, beef tacos. They were really good, but unfortunately we had been quoted the wrong price for them. Still worth the price, but it wasn't as good of a value as it initially seemed.   I had the Reuben which was gigantic. I ended up eating only half and having the rest for a very delicious breakfast the next day. First time I've had a wet sandwich like that hold up overnight! A friend and I also split the superfood salad as a suggestion from our server and it turned out to be a great option.   I'm definitely looking forward to returning for brunch, and would certainly do dinner again.

I had the Bad Breath Burger and it was delicious.  There were bits of garlic in the patty and the cream cheese combined with the greasiness of the patty made the burger ooze with goodness.  I did not put it down.  The potatoes that came with it also had garlic with it and they were delicious as well.  Yum.  Split a small Meat and Cheese Platter, but this was nothing to rave about.  Sub par deli meats and cheese slices, not even cubed.  The service was acceptable, though the tables were small and the place loud.

Dining here felt really great! Its a chill atmosphere - dim lighting, good music, plenty of eclectic knickknacks decorating the walls (Think of Applebees or Crackerbarrel)  We got and split an order of Carne Asada and a Cup of Hungarian Goulash, 2-ways.  Carne Asada ($13) - Daaaaaang. So this is pretty much a gourmet nacho plate. You've got a pile of chips with a sliced-up 6-ish ounce flank steak sitting atop. On the side of the plate you've got a very generous pile of guacamole, about a half cup ofpico de gallo, and about a half cup of pickled fennel and carrot slices. I'm going to ask that they cook the steak to "medium", rather than the standard "medium rare" next time I order, but it was DELICIOUS and there definitely WILL be a next time.  Hungarian Goulash ($6) - First, the "cup" was pretty big and satisfying! I'd say we got about 16 oz. of "not-quite-stew-but-still-pretty-packed-with-veggies-and-meat" soup. I'm sure that a "bowl" would satisfy almost anyone as a meal. TWT didn't skimp. The beef was exceptionally tender and the seasoning/spice game was on point.  Above average experience. Four stars. Thanks, TWT. :)

Local neighborhood tavern with good bar food... Part of a chain owned  with a successful formula ...  fun place to go and eat a burger-- but NOT a great place to go sit and enjoy a nice meal and conversation.    hipsters hangouts in lots of costumes .

Our Vegan friends brought us here because of the menu options for themselves. Nothing special here I had the Bob's Bad Breath Burger and my wife had their Ruben, it wasent bad it was just ok, ill never return again while in Madison!
An eclectic and well thought out menu which has rock solid staple items and fun seasonals too!

Love the look of this place, you walk in and it's like you time traveled back to the early 1900's.  Dimly lit, with candles in mason jars at every table, gorgeous chandeliers hanging from the ceiling along the bar, a shade of maroon painted on the tin ceiling, and books upon books everywhere.   Our wait was about an hour, but we got there right at the dinner rush. It's a bit crowded as the place was beyond busy and nowhere to really stand while waiting for your table. But the awesome service and outstanding food makes up for it.  Our waiter was absolutely the sweetest guy ever. He made our dining experience wonderful. Our table was a bit wobbly but not terrible to where we would have to mention it to him, but he noticed it and instantly fixed it by placing something under it. I ended up getting the Weary Traveler Ruben, which was fantastic. It came with Potato salad and Kale salad. The sandwich was so big I couldn't even eat one half as much as I wanted to.  What made the whole experience was.our server, and the host. I believe that the host was actually the owner. He was so sweet, and really liked our group as he talked to us for about 10 minutes when we first put our name in. Then, when he sat us down to our table, he talked to us even more, explained a new menu item that he made up in honor of his father, and that we were sitting next to his skis that decorated the wall!    Awesome place, can't wait to check it out again!
The food's great here. But bike, walk or come on the bus, there is little or no parking around the restaurant. When they get busy, expect slow service.

The Weary is a solid joint on the underrated east side of Madison. Is this a place where extremely liberal folks hang out for good food and drinks? Yes. Thus, if you are not willing to overhear some "hippies" as my brother would call the folks that typically hang out here, then please stay closer to the capital.   I'll be honest - I've only had the Andes sandwich, but that is because this steak sandwich literally melts in your mouth. Everything from the bun to the steak is simply delicious. I personally love avocado and it's always fresh and full of flavor.  Are there other good choices on the smaller menu? I'd be willing to bet on it.   In addition, there is a great selection of beer. I've also been here with my parents on a Sunday afternoon and there was live music. I'm pretty sure my dad was taken back to his college "hippie" days. Undeniably sweet.

I've been the the Weary on a few occasions and it's generally has not been terribly good or bad. However, on my last visit, things were oh, sooo not good. In general, the drinks are ok, nothing special. I feel like it tries too hard to be unique, but the taste is ok, so I can get over it. The menu items all look pretty good and to be fair, what I ordered last time did taste very good, if it had been done correctly.  I was there with a fairly large group of people and out of our table, the server completely forgot my drink and after she dropped the drinks off, she disappeared for about 20 minutes before we could flag her down to get her to realize she forgot my drink. Then it took another 10 to actually get it. So, first round of drink took a total of about 40 minutes for me to get. Then on to the food. I ordered the Chicken Dijonnaise, with the thigh and leg. I was told it would take extra time because they cook it fresh with every order, which I was completely fine with. When I get my food and I cut into the thigh, IT STARTED BLEEDING!!! Not just a small drip of blood like I had cut into a vein, I get that poultry some times bleeds just a tiny amount even when cooked correctly. No, it was like seriously bleeding and the texture of the meat just looked undercooked.   We flag down our server and show her my bleeding chicken and I kept on waiting for the mortification and at least ONE apology. That never happened! Her answer was "our chickens are really fresh and we butcher them ourselves everyday, so that's why it's bleeding" ARE YOU KIDDING ME??? (My mom is a chef and I'm from a country where it's perfectly normal for you to go to the open market and come home with a chicken and kill it yourself, so don't talk to me about fresh chickens!!!) So she reluctantly sent the food back.  She comes back later with my food, which by the way, they just further cooked the previous pieces of bleeding chicken instead of preparing another order for me and put it BACK ON THE SAME PLATE that it had bled on and served it back to me. You know, with the same mashed potatoes that have now absorbed all the blood that was on the plate. And the server goes "ok, so they cooked it a little more for you" in an almost condescending manner, like I was being a nuissance because I didn't want to die of food poisoning. Then she goes "so it was just a bit underdone, but I just have to educate you about our chicken. It is really fresh, we get them shipped everyday from the farm, so that's why it was bleeding."  WHAT?????? Ok, I ordered CHICKEN, not steak or duck or lamb or even pork I can let it go a bit underdone. Clearly this woman has absolutely no business working in the food industry if she thinks it's ok to have chicken slightly underdone. And I'm sorry, but I am not a six year old that needs to be "educated". I have never had this low level of service in my life. It took everything in my body to not yell at her and ruin the evening for everyone in my group, since it was a going away party.   And at the end of the evening, I still got the full bill. Not even a single drink taken off for almost giving me food poisoning! And not a single apology for making me wait for my drink, wait for my food, undercooking my food. Needless to say, I will not be back to this establishment.

Great little place. Good beer selection and a menu full of gluten free and began options but great things for the rest of us too. A little dark but that all blends in with decor. Good mid range price point but deliver higher end experience.

Love this place. The neighborhood is fantastic and the menu is eclectic with something for everyone. If you are visiting Madison and want a quality meal a little away from downtown, this is a great choice. The Bobs Bad Breath Burger is a must have but I've tried several items and always been impressed.

Weary is an awesome spot for many occasions. Let it be brunch, late night, drinks, or just to play boardgames in a cozy dimly lit room.   They have items from various cuisines: American style burgers/sandwiches, Mediterranean plate, Hungarian goulash and so on... Interesting choices all round.  The atmosphere and crowds here are quite pleasing as well. It's definitely a spot to check out on Willy!

Warm interior with lots of wood paneling. Bar runs the entire width of interior. Didn't stay for food but good selection of wisco beers I hadn't seen elsewhere. Friends have said the food is tasty. Great last stop spot on the night

Wow. Been here any number of times almost always good food/service.  This time not to much.  Waited for half hour for table, which was OK.  Ordered food and watched as many other tables got their order before us.  Finally gave up after 75 minutes.  As we were leaving the food finally came.  Unfortunately, of the 4 meals, 2 were cold.  I will try again, but  I would advise giving it a few weeks to figure out how yo run a restaurant again.
Left my credit card there by accident and my waiter RAN after us for a block or two to return it! Amazing service. Thanks Travis (I think)! Wonderful food too.

Love this place for the decor and fun vibes. The board games are perfect to go with casual dinner and beer. Service was good, friendly and accommodating. Salmon was overcooked, but I got thumbs up from the goulash and burger. The ketchup and garlic potatoes stole the show. Would come back definitely.

I only wanted to post a review to drastically refute another review.  The Weary is NOTHING like Applebee's or Cracker Barrel.  Good food.  Decent service.  Hipsters galore.  The decor is books, poems and art.  Not Applebee's

I have never been to The Weary Traveler but have always wanted to go as I have heard so many good things about it! So when my good friends from out of town suggested it for Sunday brunch, I was so excited!  Our reasoning for choosing: They open at 11:30 and still serve brunch. Great for late risers like us who want to avoid a 1.5 hr wait at other brunch locations. HOWEVER. Not sure it was worth it.  There were 4 of us who arrived as they opened. Ordered bloodies (delicious, but seemed weak) and waited for the latecomer in our party (me). When I arrived 20 min later. They had ordered an appetizer and seemed to have just gotten their drinks. 5 min later the server approached me casually and I ordered a bloody and a water. We also placed our orders. 15 min later I still hadn't received my bloody. I watched a few other tables who had arrived after us get their drinks. 25 min in, I had to go ask the bartender about my drink, turns out it was never ordered.  Note: my friends still hadn't received their CHEESE PLATE. Ordered before I had even got there.  45 min in, the cheese plate and friend's meal (ordered at the same time) arrived. Great blue cheese... But the other cheeses looked and tasted like they were something you could find in a ziplock at the grocery store.   I'm rambling. Moral of the story we ordered at 12:05pm on a Sunday. We received our food at 1:20pm with to-go boxes so my fellow diners could catch their rides back to their respective cities.  There was very little communication or explanation from our server about what was going on with our food, which felt like we spent most of the brunch wondering where our food was vs. enjoying our short time together. The server seemed very aloof and unaware of how hangry/ ridiculous it was to wait over an hour for eggs.   FINALLY. I received my 2 eggs over medium with toast, potatoes, and bacon.. Hoping it would be mind-blowing/ amazing. The eggs: overcooked and lukewarm. The toast: cold and without the preserves the menu stated they came with. The potatoes: a mixture of crispy and underdone with garlicky cheese.  I asked the server for the preserves, she gave me the options, I chose cherry. I was given pear. Mind blown.  They were not busy. I work at a brunch restaurant in Madison and I know busy. We watched many other tables receive their meals before us. They were not full. About half of the tables were unoccupied.  I am just so confused as to what happened here. It will take A LOT of bribing to get any of us back here. :/

The food was amazing here. I was a little annoyed because my husband got the same thing as I did, but we were both SOOO happy with our order that it was okay. We got the West of the Andes Sandwich with the beef tenderloin, and the sandwich was delicious. The meat was perfectly seasoned, and even though I can't handle most spicy things. This had just the right level for me. Eventhough the salad that came with it was too spicy for me to finish the sandwich and potatoes were so good that I didn't mind at all.   The space itself is a little cramped, but it's also really cool looking. The bar set up has this amazing chandelier, and there are books and board games. It just had a very comfortable atmosphere.

Ambiance, Ambiance, Ambiance. Great vibe! The food was really well done. Meat and cheese tray was delicious. Bob's Bad Breath Burger was as good a burger as I have had in Madison. Great craft beer selections and mixed drinks. Service was decent but not great.  Worth the trip.  The worst?  Parking!!!!! :(

Went here to grab a quick dinner with a friend on a Wednesday night. We were seated and taken care of promptly. There were a decent amount of people both at the bar and dinner tables. For dinner I ordered the West of the Andes sandwich. It was basically everything I like put on a sandwich. It had a creamy chipotle mayo, avocado, pico de gallo, and I chose beef tenderloin for my sandwich. Overall, the sandwich was awesome in terms of flavor. My only complaint is that the beef tenderloin was a bit tough. I wasn't able to take a bite of the sandwich without the entire piece of meat falling out. It was a bit of a mess, and embarrassing too. Ultimately, I had to eat my sandwich with a knife and fork. Our server was very kind and although she seemed busy, she managed to take care of us very well.

Chill spot in the neighborhood. I've tried the burger which was amazing. If you don't want to roll yourself home, try the West of the Andes sandwich. I ordered it with tuna and it might be my new fave. It had a slightly spicy chipotle-ish mayo on it and was served with greens. Super yummy!  Tip: The bowl of chili is huge. HUGE. It's probably similar to ordering 5 cups. No lie.

One of my favorite places to go and grab a med plate. The med plates here (humus, tabouli, salad & dressing, pita bread) are by far the best in town. It does get busy pretty fast after 7 and parking can sometimes be a pain. When it is full and busy, it gets hard to hear anyone talking and it's almost like being at a club.

A candlelit sanctuary from the cold, buzzing with energy on a frigid Sunday night. The cozy decorations and layout create the perfect, intimate setting to enjoy the delicious fare. The bad breath burger is fantastic and the goulash is perfect for one of those sub-zero Madison evenings. The grog is a delightful treat too. Overall, this neighborhood eatery will warm you up, body and soul.

Initially, I found the menu to be a little bit lacking, when it comes to what I would normally order. Talk about taking me out of my comfort zone when it comes to entrees. I quickly found myself turning to Yelp to find out what others had recommended. Bob's Bad Breath Burger was seemingly unanimous, alright Yelpers, you have spoken and I am listening.  So, what scared me the most was the idea of cream cheese on a burger... what? But to be fair, I used to think P-Nut Butter on a AJ Bomber's burger was gross. Wrong, it is delicious. *Try new things* I told myself. That burger came out and the first few bites, I couldn't tell what cheese was on it - or if I would in fact have bad breath at the end. Fast-forward to the middle of the burger, yes, there is indeed cream cheese on this burger... verdict? YUM! Not too much garlic either. I really thought this sandwich would be overpowering with mouth odors. Granted, I don't think my breath was pleasant afterwards, but it wasn't atrocious.  I liked the greens that came along with the burger, and those Yukon Gold Potato slices... I want more and I want them often! My brother enjoyed his Reuben but thought the bread was a little thick. I also tried the Hot Buttered Rum - it's a new favorite cocktail of mine. Wasn't quite as good as Bluephies' but where it lacked in mixing, it made up for in alcohol.  As I looked around the room, it looked like a great, intimate 3rd date location. I'd say first date, but for me, I wanted the burger or the Reuben - not ideal on the after-meal breath. But, it felt very Madisonian to me, the decor and atmosphere just said to me that I was in Madison. I wish the place was a little bigger. I felt cramped at my table (I'm a tall guy), my knee kept hitting the leg of my table. It was also hard to get to our table - it was very crowded and every table was full.  I could see coming back again, it was a unique experience. But I'll try a night that isn't as crowded (if that exists). Also, they have Chess Mondays... I'm not very good, but I always enjoy a good game (that I don't lose in 9 moves).

Unique, quirky atmosphere. Laid-back vibes. Good place to relax.  Yes, the Bad-Breath-Burger is amazing. As is the West of the Andes sandwich (with tuna thanks very much). If you like seared tuna as much as I do, this is a good option.  Ginger beer is highly-recommended. How many places can you even order that?   The service was quick and sincere.  If I lived in the neighborhood, this would be one of my go-to places.

If I was dying and got to pick my last place to eat out... i would pick the Weary Traveler.   Its hard for me to explain why I love this place so much.  It just has a great energy.  I have never disliked anything I ordered, they have a fantastic beer list, and it's not too expensive... what's not to like?  The West of the Andes sandwich with tuna is my personal fave but their salads are great, and my friends who love red meat say the bad breath burger is to-die-for.  I wish I could better explain my love affair with this place, but I just can't!  You have to try it out yourself!  I have never seen someone walk away disappointed.

It was very busy for a Tues evening. Loud but we were able to hold conversation. Dark everything in there..dark wood, dark lighting but not in a gloomy sad way. We liked it. Nice place to hang out. Weary Tom Ka Tofu-Hit the spot for a light meal. Coulda fooled me for being very thai cept the tofu was a bit chewy because it was fried. South of the Border Snack Plate-a bit pricey for the amount of guac and salsa we received, we needed more chips! Watch out for that mouth burnin' jalapeno! Drinks-very reasonably priced Service-very attentive, they don't accept American Express

Weary traveler I was when I hobbled in from a hangover from the night before. I had the grilled cheese sandwich and Hungarian goulash to remedy my situation. Both items did the trick, though neither were spectacularly delicious. The grilled cheese had somewhat rubbery and hard cheese, and the grilled bread was a bit too hard, not gooey and buttery. The goulash had a good soup base though the beef chunks were quite tough, unlike how others have described its tenderness.

I've heard great things about this place and I can completely see why. The ambiance alone is so charming. It really is a collection of a weary traveler. A mixture of a classy Irish pub with a quaint Parisian cafe and everything in between. I obviously made that all up, but I really loved the entire feel of the restaurant. The entrance is around the corner and you walk through two red curtains to get to the actual dining area. My friend had grabbed a table for us in the corner and it was the perfect area. a Wooden booth with lively music spanning across time. Each of the tables have a telephone on it, which unfortunately doesn't work, but adds to the decor.   My friends and I ordered a small cheese plate, 4 Bad breath Burgers, the andes sandwich, and the carne asada. Here's my opinion on them all.   -Small Cheese Plate: enough for the 6 of us to share and start the dinner. The house made crostini's made the entire dish. It was like a bagel chip but thinner and seasoned perfectly. the meat and cheese that accompanied it however, seemed like it could be from a prepackaged deli...or grocery store. All in all it was okay, and only ~$8 so it was a nice starter  -Bad Breath Burger: We asked for our burger to be medium and unfortunately it came out more well done. It didn't leave me with bad breath, but the flavors all together were pretty good. which was surprising since it's made of cream cheese, green goddess dressing, and pickapeppa sauce. Overall i enjoyed it especially because it came with garlic yukon sliced potatoes sauted in garlic.   -West of the Andes Sandwich: THE BEST THING ON THE MENU. I got it with beef tenderloin that was cooked medium rare. The brioche type bread was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside where all the flavors came together. the Chipotle mayo on it gave the sandwich the perfect kick and the the juices from the meat soaked into the bun. There were also mixed greens that came with it to balance out heaviness of the meat. If there is one thing you have to order here, this is it.   -Carne Asada: Unfortunately i wasn't able to try this but my friend really enjoyed it. It looked more like a fancy nacho plate, but the meat was very similar to that in the Andes sandwich. I would consider getting it next time, but i'm most likely going to just go with the sandwich above again.   The service was mediocre. Our food came out a little slow, but that was an easy price to pay for the deliciousness of what we ordered. This is one of the few places in Madison that I will for sure be back to visit! Next time I have to save some room for dessert because it sounded amazing.   Happy eating!!

I had every intention of taking a picture of my sandwich while I was there today but I ate it too quickly. Get the West of the Andes sandwich, I PROMISE you will love it and if you don't please come find me and I will finish it for you.

It's going to be tough for me to ever order anything other than the Bad Breath Burger here. It is so good and perfect for when I am craving a burger. A really filling and flavorful dish that comes with a little bit of salad and potatoes. There are other really interesting selections on the menu. I've tried a little bit of their carne asada, which was not bad although nowhere near as good as the burger.  I enjoy the atmosphere at this place. It is a little bit darker inside but it enables nice, intimate conversation for a group or a date night. The staff is friendly and efficient but they also mostly leave you alone, which is something I appreciate when I want to have a relaxed meal or drink.  They also have board games and delicious desserts so its perfect for a hangout.

Followed the recommendations and ordered the bad breath burger. Good Choice. Although the daily special sounded good too. Not disappointed.  Would go there again. Love, loved the chips. Good meat, nice treatment on the toppings. Place has a local underground feel. Saw a group of 8 so know they can do that. Parking could be a problem but I found a spot in back. Also think they might have live music sometimes  The ice tea was fresh and good.all in all a good choice for this out of towner who loves a good burger

The Weary Traveler Treehouse is a great place to hang out with a group of people to drink and play games.   THE FOOD: Our group ordered a bunch of things to share: -Housemade Cinnamon Roll: DO NOT LEAVE HERE WITHOUT THIS. It came out scorching hot, and was so packed with a brown sugar / cinnamon crumble and a fantastic buttery roll that it was nothing short of perfection.  -Meat & Cheese Platter: cool concept! A small is meant for 2-4 people, medium for 4-6, and large for 8-10. We got a variety of 4-5 cheeses, 4-5 meats and delicious chip/cracker/crouton things!  -Two eggs with bread and homemade jam (SUPERB!) and garlic potatoes (soggy and waaaaay overly garlicky... and I'm normally a huge fan of garlic) -Steak Sandwich: perfectly cooked with avocado! -Rueben: bread to meat ratio was off, and we didn't care for the potato salad that came with it -French Toast: again, the bread was SOOO big. Smaller bread slices would help elevate all of their dishes.   THE DRINKS: We all had different drinks... Bloody Mary was enjoyable, the mimosa was delicious, and the beer selection was on the larger side.   THE GAMES: The game selection was decent. We chose Sorry (missing a couple pieces) and Trivial Pursuit (the 1980's version hahaha).   THE ATMOSPHERE: There were families with children, couples on a date, elderly people, and groups of friends. Very diverse crowd, so everyone should feel comfortable coming! It is pretty dark, so I felt bad sitting there all afternoon and missing out on the beautiful, sunny day.
Food: Five stars. Drinks: Five stars James Franco Doppelganger: Five stars.

I bring all of my friends who come to visit to The Weary Traveler. No one has been disappointed.   I moved to Madison from Minneapolis a few months ago, and this place is definitely a favorite of the places I've tried. The West of the Andes sandwich with roasted veggies is one of the best sandwiches I've ever had.   The servers are super accommodating. It was crazy busy last time I was there, and our server came back to mention to my dairy free friend that there is butter on the bun of the burger. My friend was impressed and said most servers wouldn't take the time to do that.  Only warning is not to bring anyone hard of hearing; it's really loud at dinner time. But otherwise the ambience is pretty perfect. Pretty diverse crowd, too, which surprised me a little.
Food was excellent.  Had the bad breath burger, one of my favorite burgers I've ever had.  Bloody Mary was good too.  A must try on Willy St.

Love, love, love this place! I have daydreams about the West of the Andes sandy(sandwich). The restaurant is kind of a tight fit, has low lights, and is loud- but all in a good way! If you're downtown and have time to spare this is where you should go!

I went here on a weekend night for a late dinner. My boyfriend and I split the bad breath burger (if we both have it, it would cancel out the bad breath element...maybe :D), and the tom kar tofu soup. The burger was delicious! Very good. The soup was also awesome! I was in Thailand earlier this month and ate a ton of tom kar, and this soup did not disappoint! It was creamy, lemongrass-y, galanga-ey...totally great! The beer selection was good too. I would love to try some other drinks next time I go back!

I really want to love this place! It's different and hip; a great place to stop for a drink! Unfortunately, the bad really outweighs the good. Parking is terrible. Menu is "meh" and I've never had an "out of this world" experience with their food. Last week we stopped in, on a particularly cold day, were told "take a small table". We did, and noticed that is was freezing in there; everyone had coats, hats, even gloves on. We had told the waitress that we were going to leave since it was so cold. To which we got "k,bye!". Definitely won't be back...ever.
Sent here by a friend and glad we went. Food and service were awesome!  We had the meat and cheese platter, stew and of course tried the beer.  Everything was great!
Great menu with many local options. I have had many wonderful different meals there. Best hipster restaurant in town in a very fun neighborhood.
This place is a local gem. I had the tofu soup, which was memorably delicious! The vibe here is laid back and quaint. If I lived closer to the area, you'd likely see me here every day!
I love this place! Fantastic food and great service and amazing atmosphere.
Yummy Bloody Mary and nice selection of draft beer.  Bar ran a free shuttle to The Great Taste, which was a nice bonus.   Comfy, laid back decor with a book lined bar area.

I'm wavering between 4 starts and 5. The food is simple, rustic and heavy. When you are in the mood for something filling this hits the spot. I really like the chicken dijonnaise, more. For the garlic mashed potatoes than the chicken. In winter they have warm cocktails served in mugs that warm you right up.

My husband, son, and I needed brunch and scoped out this place because it wasn't downtown and wouldn't have the Packer fan crowd. We waited in the car about 15 minutes for it to open at 11:30am, but it was better than waiting an hour at ElDorado.   My son really liked the bob's bad breath burger and loves trying different burgers. It has a couple different sauces so he said it was pretty wet and seemed to have a cream cheese layer, too. He ordered it medium and it was closer to medium rare but he was good with that. He said the mixed greens had a dressing that was sort of spicy. Husband had the walleye sandwich and he agreed the dressing on the greens was spicy. Sandwich needed more poblano tartar sauce. His Bloody Traveler drink was bland and just tasted like weird-tasting flavored vodka. I had the West of the Andes sandwich with a tuna steak. Steak is a gross exaggeration. It was a great, fresh tasting sandwich with the avocado and pico de gallo, but the tuna was SO thin that it was hard to taste it. I had the "grog" which in my world is called glogg. Very warm, well seasoned, heavy alcohol taste that was accentuated by sipping in the fumes.  Ok, now for the bad news. The place is covered in cobwebs! Hanging from the bookshelves, all over the bathroom walls, and coating the air vents. We tried to focus on the charm--my son said it looked like a place that James Bond meets an informant--but please clean!
Not too expensive for a great meal! It would be hard to find something you didn't like on the menu.

Great food and excellent customer service. Had lunch on Sat. Went with son and his wife. We're chatting when bill came. Glanced at bill, misread bill. Payed way to much. Contacted Weary Traveler regarding my error. They were happy to refund my overpayment. Receive the check very quick. We will be back for more great food.

Wonderful, late dinner a few nights ago.  Wait staff was beyond great!  Menu is small, but it doesn't look like you can make a bad choice.  I had the Carne Asada and my friend had the Walleye Sandwich - both were just what we were expecting without much of a wait.  The margaritas are excellent and there is a well rounded beer list!

The food is delicious; the food and drinks are reasonably priced; staff is friendly and prompt.  The only reason I'm giving this a 3 instead of a 5 is because every time I've been there THE MUSIC HAS BEEN SO LOUD MY EARS HURT!  I've only got one set of ears and if I lose my hearing I'll never get it back.  Turn down the volume, Weary Traveler, and you'll get a 5 from me!

My husband and I were here over the weekend (accidentally) for brunch - I forgot they serve brunch late! YAY for us. I got their breakfast sandwich and was not disappointed - it was great. I appreciate the healthy dose of greens for a side, it made me feel much better about the massive amount of bread I consumed in my sandwich.  My husband ordered 'Le Toaste' and said that he would do a full order - the bar tender kindly suggested that he start with a half order (because most people only finish half of their order or now order the 1/2 size) and he said that if he still felt he wanted more, he would bring him the other serving out and charge accordingly. I thought that was incredibly thoughtful and just plain good customer service. His tip was spot on - my husband was absolutely stuffed off of a half order. What a steal!

Bringing my parents up to Madison for the weekend, we had one mandatory stop: The Weary Traveler. This was not my first visit, so I went for my tried and true, Grilled Cheese with side mixed greens and a Nessalla kombucha.  My parents and husband all had Bad Breath Burgers. Needless to say, I had an exceptional meal, but insisted we keep the windows rolled down on the way home. Highly recommended!

If the Weary Traveler were my neighborhood bar, I'd be there all the time. My review may be a bit skewed since it's an hour drive for me so by the time I get there I am starving and grouchy. We were in the neighborhood a while back and wanted a burger. I hadn't been to the WT in 3 years so decided to give it a try (btw, was very happy with it the first time).  There was a fun Arcade Fire meets Trampled By Turtles band playing and the volume level was perfect for chatting. The service was charming if not a bit stand-offish. I ordered a Bloody Mary and my husband got a beer. The bloody was pretty good but every sip I took just reminded me that it was missing something. I couldn't put my finger on it. It was not missing horseradish however (hot damn!), or pickled goodness-- the skewer was nicely loaded with some pickled gems.  For food I had Bob's Bad Breath Burger. My husband had the Reuben. We shared a cup of the goulash. I would go back for this goulash. Delicious.  The burger was not a good as I remember from last time. Maybe my expectations were higher... I don't know. It was good-- it just did not have that wow factor. The hubs' Reuben was a tasty treat! I think I could give this place 5 stars if the menu had changed at all in the last 3 years. I like more variety. I'm all for small menus as long as they evolve.

Went to here on a Sunday afternoon.  It wasn't very busy but the service was super slow.  I got the Bad Breath Burger.  The meat was really good,  organic beef. The bun was so thick and dry that I has to set it aside in order to taste the meat. Seemed like, aside from the cheese, the rest of the toppings listed on the menu were non existent. The potatoes were pretty tasty.  I had seen via their website or a review that they supposedly had an impressive selection of hot sauces. When I asked the server about them he said they red hot, Tabasco,  or their house made.  I asked for the house.  It was a heavily vinegar flavored mild sauce that didn't deserve to be called "hot" sauce. Btw, I'm not one who tries to be buddies with the server, but this guy was pretty much phoning it in.  Took forever to find him to take our order and I had to ask about specials.  Overall not a terrible experience, but I'm in no hurry to return. Also, in the year 2015 is it really that difficult to get separate checks at a table of 6?

We dined at The Weary Traveler as a group around 7pm on a weekday. The atmosphere was loud-ish, with music, but not too loud to have a conversation. Service was good and prompt, and food was good. I particularly liked the Mediterranean platter which we shared as an appetizer. I couldn't resist the Underground Meat's Cervalas, which was a sausage stuff with cheese and wrapped with bacon, with sides of fingerling potatoes and coleslaw, and it didn't disappoint. The deco of the place is quite cool- dim lights, vintage globes, books, violas, art.. and lots of plants.

I've been to The Weary Traveler twice now and it's something of a mixed bag. The food and service are good on the whole despite the fact that the place is wall-to-wall with people. It's managing that wall-to-wall crowd that is preventing them from being a really good, possibly great place. I can't help but feel that its a victim of its own success. Just so you're aware, both my visits were made with different friends on Saturday evenings in winter.  Food was fine but sort of inconsistent on both visits.   On both trips, my friends and I had the south of the border platter as an appetizer. The pico was good, chips just fine, and the pickled vegetables tasty and crisp, with the right amount of bite and spice. The guacamole was good, but may need a shake of salt...taste it and be the judge. However, both tips resulted in vastly different amounts of the items on the spread. The escabeche pickled vegetables were almost non-existent on the second visit, and my dining partner was the first to express her disappointment as that was her favorite part. I agreed, as on my first visit I was served at least 3 times the amount.  On one trip, I enjoyed a cup of good tom kha tofu. the soup was evenly spiced, the vegetables fresh and tofu firm to the tooth. Very nice. I alomost ordered a bowl again on my second trip, but wanted to try something new.  Instead, I took a chance and ordered the special on my second visit. Fried smelt with parsnip pancakes, arugula*, and chile-blood orange syrup. This is a very Great Lakes-oriented dish that has been given a world flair that had a ton of potential. Unfortunately, it worked out to be an assembly of elements rather than a complete meal. I ate less than half of it.  I was served a plate that was the rough equivalent of pasta bowl in size and shape. , The smelt were fine but a bit flavorless, most likely a result of a batter that was too thin (and probably lacked beer). The parsnip pancakes were not pancakes in the sense of potato pancakes. Instead, they were large croquettes of puree with some chunks, nicely friend on the outside and about 3 inches in diameter and 1 inch (!!!) thick. The arugula was fresh and crisp, but lacked any touch of the chile-blood orange syrup, which instead was an afterthought put on the potato cakes. The only indication it was there was a tiny spot of red color; it provided no discernible flavor to my meal. Total disappointment.  My dining partner told me she ordered the chicken dijionnaise every time she was there, and after a bite of it I couldn't blame her. The chicken was cooked marvelously and the sauce more of a light mustard cream sauce than a thick mayo-mustard sauce I had expected. The green beans looked bright and fresh and I sampled the garlic mashed potatoes and found them mild and well-made. I could see why she liked it so much!  Still, despite the crowd, we were seated quickly and treated to attentive service by out waiter. The host was a little rude on both visits, but I put it down to him being harried dealing with the crowd. When he seated us, he was very polite. Bartenders were pleasant and quick on both visits once you grabbed their attention. Be aggressive, but don't wave money. =o)  A couple of miscellaneous sparks: a good selection of gluten-free, vegan, and vegetarian items are called out on the menu. There are some interesting alcohol-free drinks on the drink menu. Also, both time I was there it was the winter, and they had some hot drinks on a small menu as well -- nice touch!  I'll certainly be back; I think my order on my second visit was just poorly executed. I'm presupposing the carne asada would be good, as would be a few other items. A third visit in spring should yield a different menu and a final measure.  Looking for a recommendation? From me personally, I'd say it's inconclusive. From the crowds and the number of bad breath burgers coming out of the kitchen, I'd say give it a try.

Super good food. I had the Goulash...it's not like any goulash I've ever had and that's a good thing. Hearty chunks of tender beef with vegetables in a broth with a slight kick from the spicy paprika. It ate more like a stew than a goulash. I'm not from Madison but if I have the opportunity to visit this place again I will. Great recommendation from a local friend.

We are restaurant owners so may be a little more particular than others but there is a level of service that one comes to expect as basic care.  The Traveler has consistently not fulfilled these basic needs.  I think it is a top down attitude.  On our last visit there was one older guy waiting on the entire room.  It was lunch and any hope of getting out in a timely matter was out the window.  The dude took our order and delivered the food, that was it.  For a second glass of wine I had to flag down an annoyed lady bartender.  They were spread very thin so it is understandable, BUT, there was what appeared to be two or three owner/manager types chatting and sampling wines at the bar.  Unbelievable! The customer is king is not a belief these people hold dear.  The food is ok but really needs a fresh revamp.  Cheese in the potato salad is unneeded, the huge pile of chips with the Carne Asada is ridiculous, the pickled garlic cloves are inedible.

Loved the atmosphere. Food and service...not so much. Our first server was obviously preoccupied with something because he tried to take our order the second we sat down and when we asked for a minute to look at drink menu, he didn't return for 10. Then, we never saw him again after he took our order and a nice young lady took over but was very inattentive. Never asked to refill our water glasses which were nearly empty the entire meal. My daughter's boyfriend and I both ordered the Bob's Bad Breath Burger and asked for them to be cooked to medium and they came out very well done. Not a hint of juiciness every delicious burger requires. The HUNK of unmelted cream cheese is probably one of the worst ideas I've ever tasted on a burger, probably because it didn't melt and wasn't mixed with some of the other crucial ingredients were either totally absent or hardly detectable (green goddess dressing, caramelized onions, Pickapeppa Sauce.) I'm totally willing to have bad breath over a delectable burger, but not this one. It haunted me for hours. Blech. The yukon gold potatoes were strange, half of them were crisp like potato chips and the other half was totally soft. Good flavor, but odd. The mixed greens needed a lot of help as they were just that-a small handful of mixed greens with a little dressing. No other veggies or croutons. Would never recommend this burger to anyone. My daughter ordered the Grilled Walleye Sandwich and it was just ok. The fish was not whole but broken pieces and needed help...more flavorful tartar sauce or something?? We were very let down by this place that had great potential to making our long drive to Madison worth the trip.

We stumbled across this place by accident...a happy accident! Very busy on a Friday night, but we doubled up with some strangers (my partner's idea) and were able to take a larger table. Food was top notch. When's the last time I had Hungarian Goulash? Tonight. Huge bowl full of tender meat, veggies, and spice. Even though they were very busy, the staff was great. Food arrived plenty fast and staff stopped by often.  The ambiance was eclectic to say the least. A lot of art and a lot of stuff. Could have spent an hour just looking around. Happy happy find!

The food was an original take on a lot of "typical" plates - everyone in our group enjoyed what they ordered! The waitstaff was incredibly accomodating to us as we had a wheelchair in our party. It was just a bit cramped/loud, which isn't much my style, but necessarily a negative for a lot of people. While it didn't leave a lasting memory or need to go back anytime soon, the restaurant certainly will not disappoint.

The Weary Traveler is a cool, dark, large space for weary travelers to rest, drink, and eat. I thought the local beer prices were very reasonable and got the immense Bob's Bad Breath Burger. It was a very fine mix of meat topped with an aromatic combination of items, moderated by an over-sized of cream cheese. I could have used less cream cheese but was grateful for the generous plate of food after driving up from Chicago. My friend got the tomato-basil frittatta, which was reportedly very good but not as substantial as my meal. Staff was very nice as well.

Parking was a pain (as it usually is on Willy street), but I wouldn't mind coming down here again for some solid grub. We got the bad breath burger and West of the Andes sandwich.   The bad breath burger was a beast of a thing, most definitely flavorful, and in this garlic-lover's opinion, could have been even more garlicky! I also enjoyed the potatoes it came with, crispy and well seasoned. West of the Andes sandwich was quite original, not something I've had before and was a little bit on the tough side. Besides that, flavors were delicious.

Normally I would give this place 4 (or maybe 5) stars as it had a lot of character and the food was good.   However we had pretty terrible service. We were sat in a corner and basically forgotten about. While it was super busy, there were 4 servers (and a bartender) on duty. It took 30 minutes before we got a menu, then another 30 or so before we got anything to drink (not even water). In all the meal took 2 hours from when we were seated, which would have been okay if I wasn't thirsty for the first hour.   Not sure I would go back unless it was at an off-time, or if I do go back I'll make sure not to get the same server. The guy was just really disorganized. Did things like bus tables (despite there being 3 clean tables open/no need to take care of such things immediately) instead of refilling drinks/etc. Felt like a bit of a d*ck short tipping the guy, but the service really was that bad/I was worried it'd take a half hour to get my credit card or change back so I did the best I could.
Cornbread Update:  I think they must have tweaked their recipe, because I tried a piece of the vegan cornbread again and it was perfect. Thanks, Weary Bakers!
Had an excellent grilled walleye sandwich and my husband had a reuben.  Both were delicious as were my garlic potato chips and his potato salad.

Average to below average.  Please tell me the special, I do not want to read it off a chalkboard set off to the side. I know that is a little diva-ish of me, but this place is small. I had to stand next to another table to read the special. I felt intrusive to the other diners. They deserve their space and I should be told the special. The service is kind of slow.   So the food?  Average. It does not make me want to come back. I ordered the highly rated West of the Andes Sandwich. And it was a torta. Nothing special. The portion and side was small for the price. I was just underwhelmed. As I write this, I sigh. It has some delicious neighbors on Willy Street, so I will probably always skip over this place.

Great beer, love the location, and staff is nice.  Atmosphere is friendly vibe, and this has become an East side icon for good reason.my only complaints are difficulty in finding a place to park, and I struggle with limited menu choices. You can only have the bad breath burger so many times ....

A friend from Madison recommended this place for a stop on our cross country drive. The set up was a little crowded and tight but other than that, it had a great atmosphere. The bad breath burger was DELICIOUS and messy and all sorts of wonderful. The grilled cheese was good. Maybe something more exciting could be done with it but it still served its purpose as a classic favorite.

This place keeps on impressing me. Today I had the bad breath burger and it was filled with so many different flavors. I also love their chili with or without meat!! Today I warmed up with some coffee. The coffee I'd barriques brand roasted here in Madison. Really can't go wrong here!

We come here on cold and dreary days and hunker down with a Bobs bad breath burger, a beer, and board game. Maybe finish with the house special, grog,  if it's been an especially bad day. We always leave feeling better. Try it!
